user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY_NP) && defined(HAVE_GETPID)
  /* NetBSD style */
  cpuset_t *cpuset_ptr;
  cpuset_ptr = cpuset_create ();
  if (NULL != cpuset_ptr)
  {
    if (0 == sched_getaffinity_np (getpid (), cpuset_size (cpuset_ptr),
                                   cpuset_ptr))
    {
      cpuid_t cpu_num;
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && defined(HAVE_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF)
      unsigned int max_num = 0;
      long sc_value;
      sc_value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN);
      if (0 < sc_value)
        max_num = (unsigned int) sc_value;
      if (0 < max_num)
      {
        ret = 0;
        for (cpu_num = 0; cpu_num < max_num; ++cpu_num)
          if (0 < cpuset_isset (cpu_num, cpuset_ptr))
            ++ret;
      }
      else /* Combined with the next 'if' */
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF && HAVE_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF */
      if (1)
      {
        int res;
        cpu_num = 0;
        ret = 0;
        do
        {
          res = cpuset_isset (cpu_num++, cpuset_ptr);
          if (0 < res)
            ++ret;
        } while (0 <= res);
      }
#ifdef __NetBSD__
      if (0 == ret)
      {
        /* On NetBSD "unset" affinity (exactly zero CPUs) means
           "all CPUs are available". */
        ret = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_ ();
      }
#endif /* __NetBSD__ */
    }
    cpuset_destroy (cpuset_ptr);
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY_NP && HAVE_GETPID */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_:
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
  /* Do not use sysctl() function on GNU/Linux even if
     sysctl() is available */
#ifndef __linux__
#ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The number of available logical CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.logicalcpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* FreeBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("kern.smp.cpus", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The current number of CPUs available to run threads */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.activecpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* OpenBSD, NetBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.ncpuonline", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The old/alternative name for "hw.activecpu" */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.availcpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* OpenBSD, NetBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Darwin: The MIB name for "hw.activecpu" */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_AVAILCPU};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU */
#endif /* ! __linux__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
MISRA C Rule 17.8 prohibits modifying a function parameter (the pointer object itself shall not be modified; the object pointed-to may be). Both functions shown (mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ and mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_) have no parameters (they are declared with void). Therefore there are no function parameters in these bodies that could be modified, and no fragments that violate Rule 17.8.

Notes on other code that might look relevant but are not violations of Rule 17.8:
- cpuset_ptr is a local pointer variable; assignments to it (e.g. cpuset_ptr = cpuset_create();) modify a local variable, not a function parameter.
- Passing &ret, cpuset_ptr, or other local addresses to library/system calls may allow those called functions to modify the pointed-to objects; that is permitted by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). These are calls to other functions, not modifications of parameters of the current functions.
- Local variables (ret, cpu_num, res, sc_value, etc.) are modified within the functions; Rule 17.8 is specific to function parameters and thus does not apply to these local variable modifications.

Because of the above, there are no code fragments in the provided code that should be investigated for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
